explanation:
For checking whether the function uses any compiler/language extensions you must know which conditional macros and platform APIs are in play and whether any of those are compiler-specific extensions or carry extension attributes:

- __linux__: predefined platform macro (commonly provided by compilers). Needed to decide if use of a compiler-provided/predefined macro constitutes use of a language extension in this build.
- HAVE_SYSCTLBYNAME, HAVE_SYSCTL, HAS_DECL_CTL_HW, HAS_DECL_HW_NCPUONLINE, HAS_DECL_HW_AVAILCPU: build-config / feature-test macros that control compilation of extension/platform-specific code paths. You must know how these are defined (by the build system or headers) to determine which code is actually compiled and whether those macros themselves come from compiler-specific extensions.
- sysctlbyname: platform API used inside conditionals. Its declaration (header and attributes) must be inspected to see if it uses compiler-specific language extensions or nonstandard linkage/attributes.
- sysctl: same as above — check its declaration and any compiler-specific attributes or nonstandard prototypes.
- CTL_HW, HW_NCPUONLINE, HW_AVAILCPU: platform constants/macros used to build MIBs. Their definitions (in system headers) may reveal nonstandard or implementation-specific constructs; they control whether platform-specific sysctl usage is compiled.
- size_t: type from standard headers; include/definition should be confirmed to ensure no nonstandard typedef/extension is being used.
- NULL: standard macro; included because it appears in the calls and its definition could be implementation-defined.

Providing these symbols (their presence/definitions/headers) lets the analyzer determine which #if/#ifdef branches are active and whether any of the referenced identifiers or their declarations rely on compiler-specific language extensions.
